### 1.2.1 â€“ What Are Factors?

A {{< glink factor >}} of a number is a whole number that divides it evenly â€” with no {{< glink remainder >}}.

**Example:**

The factors of 12 are: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6 and 2

Thatâ€™s because:

1 Ã— 12 = 12

2 Ã— 6 = 12

3 Ã— 4 = 12

:::{.callout-note icon=false appearance="simple" collapse=true title="ðŸ§  Can a number have just one factor?"}
Only one number does: **1**. It only has itself as a factor. Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s not considered prime *or* composite!
:::

### 1.2.3 â€“ Prime vs. Composite

A **prime number** has only 2 factors: 1 and itself.
Examples: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13...

A **composite number** has more than 2 factors.
Examples: 4, 6, 8, 9, 10...

:::{.callout-tip .realworld-box icon=false title="ðŸŒ In the Real World"}
Prime numbers play a big role in **encryption**, which keeps your data safe when you shop or message online.
:::

---

### 1.2.4 â€“ Prime Factorization and Factor Trees

### 1.2.5 â€“ Why Do Prime Factors Matter?

Later on, you'll use prime factorization to:

* Simplify fractions
* Find the **greatest common factor**
* Factor algebraic expressions
* Solve equations

So this isn't just about numbers â€” it's about developing tools that will unlock Algebra.
